user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType:
```c
void UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, size_t ReturnSize, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    if (ReturnSize > 0)
    {
        /* Check for existing buffer and re-use if same size (should be!) */
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);
        if (StubPtr != NULL && StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize != ReturnSize)
        {
            UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
            StubPtr = NULL;
        }

        if (StubPtr == NULL)
        {
            StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);
            if (StubPtr == NULL)
            {
                UtAssert_Abort("Cannot set return buffer - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
            }
            else
            {
                StubPtr->FuncKey           = FuncKey;
                StubPtr->EntryType         = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER;
                StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr = malloc(ReturnSize);
                if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr == NULL)
                {
                    UtAssert_Abort("Cannot allocate data buffer - malloc() failed!");
                }
                else
                {
                    memset(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, 0, ReturnSize);
                    StubPtr->ModeFlags |= UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF;
                }

                StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize = ReturnSize;
            }
        }

        if (StubPtr != NULL)
        {
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position       = 0;
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr = TypeName;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
All other pointer uses in this function either already have appropriate const qualification or are used to modify the pointed-to data and therefore should not be const. Specifically:
- The parameter TypeName is already declared as const char * (appropriate for read-only string data).
- The local pointer declaration UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr is used to modify the stub entry fields (FuncKey, EntryType, Data, ModeFlags), so it must be a non-const pointer to allow mutation.
- The buffer pointer assignment StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr = malloc(ReturnSize) and the subsequent memset(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, 0, ReturnSize) indicate the buffer is intended to be writable, so BasePtr must not be const-qualified.
- Calls to UT_GetStubEntry return a mutable entry that is subsequently modified (cleared, reinitialized), so returning a pointer-to-const would be inappropriate here.
Therefore, the only fragment that may violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is the assignment of the const-qualified TypeName to the ContentTypeStr field — this suggests ContentTypeStr might be declared as a non-const char * and should be reviewed to determine if it should instead be const char * to preserve the const qualification.
